quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we focus on the journey of becoming a great PM, including crossing the canyon from IC to manager, the importance of expanding your scope, and how to create opportunities where you get more responsibility as a PM.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets up three actionable growth themes for PMs: transitioning to management, expanding scope, and proactively earning more responsibility.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Fareed Mosavat is the Chief Development Officer at Reforge where he's been for over two and a half years.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete data point about Fareed’s current role and tenure, grounding his credibility as a product leader.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Before that, he spent three and a half years at Slack leading a lot of their growth efforts, about a year at Instacart leading a number of their key growth analytics and product efforts.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights specific examples of leading growth across major companies, signaling the episode’s practical growth-oriented lens.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: something that I only learned during our chat is that he spent six years at Pixar doing character simulation, rigging, and building 3D animation tools.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable, non-obvious background detail that suggests transferable skills and unconventional paths into product leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Coda and Amplitude
quotes.text: Well, we've always thought of Amplitude as being about supporting the full product loop. Think collect data, inform, vet, ship experiments, and learn.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Provides a clear end-to-end framework (“full product loop”) teams can use to structure growth and product learning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Coda and Amplitude
quotes.text: So the big aha was seeing how many customers were using Amplitude to analyze experiments, use segments for outreach, and send data to other destinations.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Highlights concrete customer behaviors that can guide product expansion decisions and prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Coda and Amplitude
quotes.text: Experiment and CDP came out of listening to and observing our customers.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that adjacent product bets are often best derived from direct observation of how customers already use your product.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Coda and Amplitude
quotes.text: So Amplitude tries to meet customers where they are.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A practical product principle for reducing adoption friction by aligning with customers’ current maturity and workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Coda and Amplitude
quotes.text: If you're ping-ponging between lots of documents and spreadsheets, make your life better, and start using Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Direct, practitioner-oriented advice to consolidate fragmented workflows into a single system to improve execution efficiency.

quotes.topic_title: Fareed’s career overview across companies
quotes.text: Today, I am the chief development officer at Reforge where I help run all of our content teams, parts of our operations, and our partnerships with wonderful experts like yourself.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Highlights a cross-functional product leadership scope (content, ops, partnerships) that practitioners can model when defining senior product roles.

quotes.topic_title: Fareed’s career overview across companies
quotes.text: We're responsible for the self-service business at Slack all the way from first sign up, first team creation through to the first invites, activation, expansion, modernization, and even connecting the dots with our SMB sales team to help nurture some of those small self-service teams into larger commitments through our sales team.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A concrete end-to-end lifecycle/growth funnel map that teams can use to structure ownership, metrics, and initiatives across activation-to-revenue.

quotes.topic_title: Fareed’s career overview across companies
quotes.text: I built one of the first growth teams at Instacart for about a year and a half in the middle of their acceleration.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A specific example of when to form a dedicated growth team—during a rapid scaling phase—useful for org design decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Fareed’s career overview across companies
quotes.text: I got there through a startup that I was an engineer at, basically started as an engineer, ended as a head of product over the course of a couple of years, and then got acquired into Zynga,
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: An actionable career progression pattern (engineering → product leadership) that suggests a non-linear path can be leveraged via startups and acquisitions.

quotes.topic_title: Pixar years and product mindset roots
quotes.text: I was super interested in computer graphics. I'd actually been an intern there, was very lucky to be interested in that in the moment where they were really accelerating the growth of the company going from like the whole company is working on one film to like, "Okay. We're trying to release a film every 18 months."
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A concrete example of how scaling cadence (one film to every 18 months) forces organizational and process changes product leaders can learn from.

quotes.topic_title: Pixar years and product mindset roots
quotes.text: I think in a lot of ways is the root of why I love doing product management because everything I worked on was at the intersections of interesting creative problems, interesting technical problems, and interesting storytelling problems.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for product work as the intersection of creative, technical, and narrative constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Pixar years and product mindset roots
quotes.text: I think if I connect the dots backwards to the Steve Jobsism is the beginning of how I got interested in solving high-level strategic problems across a bunch of different people doing different kinds of work and maybe how I got relatively good at it.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Highlights a practitioner-relevant skill: getting better at strategy by operating across diverse functions and disciplines.

quotes.topic_title: Pixar years and product mindset roots
quotes.text: It was because even as an engineer, I was sitting in the middle of those pieces, but I got bored, which sounds crazy, and decided to jump into a startup that nobody had ever heard of that had eight employees in 2006, and the rest is history from there.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career move—leaving a dream job for an unknown 8-person startup—that challenges conventional “stay for prestige” thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Key Pixar lesson: outcomes over realism
quotes.text: What I learned there is that actually, you're trying to deliver an end experience, and product, and story to your viewers, to your audience.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A product mental model: optimize for the audience’s experienced outcome rather than internal notions of correctness.

quotes.topic_title: Key Pixar lesson: outcomes over realism
quotes.text: It doesn't actually matter what's real. It matters what you see on the screen. It matters the emotion that it creates, the story that it creates, how it reinforces all of the other pieces.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that perceived experience and emotion can matter more than technical realism or purity.

quotes.topic_title: Key Pixar lesson: outcomes over realism
quotes.text: So the technical pieces were just a means to that end.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization: treat engineering and technical decisions as tools in service of the customer experience.

quotes.topic_title: Key Pixar lesson: outcomes over realism
quotes.text: So, of course, we used real physics and real math behind the scenes to do stuff, but if you had to box the numbers to make it look right, that's the right thing to do.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A concrete example of bending “correct” inputs to achieve the right output—useful for product/UX tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Key Pixar lesson: outcomes over realism
quotes.text: I feel like I go back to that a lot as I think about product development not just from an engineering and technical standpoint, but from what's in your strategy doc isn't that important. It's actually just an input into the end experience that you're trying to deliver for customers.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A practical reframing: strategy docs are inputs, not the goal—judge success by the delivered customer experience.

quotes.topic_title: What a Chief Development Officer does at Reforge
quotes.text: So I think what's unique about Reforge versus a traditional software startup, or a SaaS company, or all the other things you see is that we're not just a software company.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A clear positioning lens: Reforge is a blended product + content + experience business, not a typical SaaS model.

quotes.topic_title: What a Chief Development Officer does at Reforge
quotes.text: at the end of the day, our job is to help unlock the expertise that's locked in the heads of the greatest operators in the world.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A memorable mission statement that frames content/program building as an “expertise extraction and packaging” problem.

quotes.topic_title: What a Chief Development Officer does at Reforge
quotes.text: A lot of that is a product experience that in some ways, like a Pixar movie, there's the technical aspects and the UX aspects, but there's also all of the content, and the partners that we work with, and those pieces.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A useful analogy for practitioners building hybrid experiences: product quality includes content and partner ecosystems, not just UX/tech.

quotes.topic_title: What a Chief Development Officer does at Reforge
quotes.text: I've really found myself drawn to, "Is this an interesting problem that I believe I can bring something valuable to the table? Can I help solve this in some meaningful way, and will I learn something great and new from this role?"
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A practical decision framework for choosing roles based on problem/impact/learning rather than title or ladder progression.

quotes.topic_title: What a Chief Development Officer does at Reforge
quotes.text: I've gone up and down the title stack from VP down to ICPM, from engineer to product, from product to this new thing and content.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career move example that normalizes non-linear paths and “downshifts” in title to pursue better problems.

quotes.topic_title: Reforge scale and programs today
quotes.text: I believe we are at just around 150 total employees across the whole company right now.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Concrete scale data point that helps practitioners benchmark what it takes to run a mature cohort-based education business.

quotes.topic_title: Reforge scale and programs today
quotes.text: That doesn't include our executives and residents, subject matter experts, and the partners we work with. That's full-time employees working on the business.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Highlights an operating model where a core FTE team is extended by a broader expert network—useful for thinking about leverage and resourcing.

quotes.topic_title: Reforge scale and programs today
quotes.text: When I first started working with it, it was a scrappy operation of just a handful of folks, but we've grown quite a bit of over the last year.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A succinct growth story that underscores how quickly an organization can scale from scrappy to sizable in a year.

quotes.topic_title: Reforge scale and programs today
quotes.text: With that, we support, I believe, now 19 total cohort-based programs across product, engineering, marketing, and growth-related topics as well as a bunch of new experiences that we're working on for the coming future here in the next year.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Specific example of portfolio breadth and expansion cadence that can inform how leaders think about scaling programs across functions.

quotes.topic_title: Reforge scale and programs today
quotes.text: We have well over 10,000 active members on the platform, about a dozen executives and residents that work to help us deliver those programs, and hundreds of partners.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Clear scale metrics plus a leveraged delivery model (execs-in-residence + partners) that practitioners can use as a reference point.

quotes.topic_title: Why becoming a better PM is hard
quotes.text: I think there's an idea that Naval Ravikant talked about on Twitter and in blog posts a long time ago, this concept of specific knowledge that can only be gathered by actually doing the work. A lot of product management, really, is like that. You get better by doing it, and so you start in the same place, if that makes sense.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Frames PM growth as “specific knowledge” that can’t be front-loaded via credentials—only earned through real execution.

quotes.topic_title: Why becoming a better PM is hard
quotes.text: So I think this is what makes it so hard is that there's not any upfront training you can really do to prepare yourself or even knock down the door to break in.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that courses and prep don’t reliably translate into getting (or being ready for) the first PM role.

quotes.topic_title: Why becoming a better PM is hard
quotes.text: So what we tried to do at Reforge is we are focused on helping people accelerate that learning loop. It's not, "Hey, if you take this class, now you're qualified to be a PM." It's not really like that. I don't know if that's possible.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Offers a practical model for training: accelerate learning loops rather than “certify” competence.

quotes.topic_title: Why becoming a better PM is hard
quotes.text: You can't do homework, you can't do exercises, you can't do fake stuff. You have to work on real products at real companies with real customers, with real data to get better at product management.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on how to actually improve: prioritize real product reps over simulated practice.

quotes.topic_title: Why becoming a better PM is hard
quotes.text: At the core is you have to actually execute and deliver great products, and you have to do it over, and over, and over again.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A memorable distillation that PM mastery is repetition of real delivery, not one-time learning.

quotes.topic_title: PM growth loop: execute, generalize, communicate, scale
quotes.text: At the core, again, at the top of the loop is execution. You have to have a real problem. You're working on with real customers that you want to solve in some way. So, you're executing. You're delivering. You're learning at the beginning. It's all about execution.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Defines the foundation of Fareed’s PM growth loop: real customer problems and shipping as the primary driver of learning early on.

quotes.topic_title: PM growth loop: execute, generalize, communicate, scale
quotes.text: So it's not just, "Okay. Now, I know what the best settings page for Slack is." It's, "What generalizations did you make? What are the things that you can take that are applicable to other stuff?"
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Highlights the leveling-up move from project-specific execution to extracting transferable principles you can reuse across domains.

quotes.topic_title: PM growth loop: execute, generalize, communicate, scale
quotes.text: The generalization is, "Oh, for products that had a high bar to activation, sometimes more set up and higher friction, good friction could actually help those customers be successful. There are other kinds of products that are high-intent where they know what they need to do to have simple actions where lowering friction might be the right thing."
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A concrete Instacart onboarding example that challenges the default “always reduce friction” playbook by introducing “good friction.”

quotes.topic_title: PM growth loop: execute, generalize, communicate, scale
quotes.text: Then, the next bit is communication, and I think this is a bit that a lot of product managers, obviously, and any job miss, but you can't just do the work. You have to actually communicate the work. You have to talk about what you're doing, what you've generalized, what you've learned so that you can hit the next step, which is scale your opportunities.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Connects communication directly to earning bigger scope—making it a necessary step in the loop, not a “nice to have.”

quotes.topic_title: PM growth loop: execute, generalize, communicate, scale
quotes.text: No one knows what you're thinking if you don't tell them. So if you don't communicate, you don't have control over those scaled opportunities. Usually, your manager, or the organization, or the company does.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A blunt reminder that visibility and narrative shape who gets entrusted with larger, higher-unknown work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsorship, trust, and creating bigger opportunities
quotes.text: The scale opportunity piece of the step often requires someone from outside to notice that you're doing something really well and trust you with a bigger opportunity. I think of this as sponsorship, not mentorship.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Clarifies a key career-growth mechanism: advancement often hinges on sponsorship (trusted bets) rather than just mentorship (skill-building).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsorship, trust, and creating bigger opportunities
quotes.text: This idea that it's what you do and that's multiplied by your ability to show that work and communicate it, and that's the impact that you can have, but you have to have not just impact on the customers, but also on the organization.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Offers an actionable “impact equation” and expands impact beyond customer outcomes to organizational influence.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsorship, trust, and creating bigger opportunities
quotes.text: I've treated a huge part of my job as not just moving the numbers, but also teaching the organization how our growth model works, how the pieces fit together, what our customers care about, what's working, what's not working, and that creates a lot of, A, leverage in other parts of the organization because they can do better work by having more information, but also, B, trust.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Shows a concrete method for building trust: operationalize “teaching the org” as part of the job to create leverage and credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsorship, trust, and creating bigger opportunities
quotes.text: I think it is easier to find sponsors, communicate, and create leverage if the thing you're working on is in the top four or five most important things the company is working on.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Practical career strategy: choose problems with executive visibility to increase sponsorship odds.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsorship, trust, and creating bigger opportunities
quotes.text: So I call this going two stack levels up, two stack levels down in terms of your curiosity and what you understand, and also, knowing what's to the left and what's to the right.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable curiosity framework for building cross-org context and becoming sponsor-worthy.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta (SOC 2 compliance)
quotes.text: SOC 2 is a way to prove your company's taking proper security measures to protect customer data and builds trust with customers and partners, especially those with serious security requirements.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames SOC 2 as a trust-building mechanism that directly impacts customer and partner confidence, especially in high-security contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta (SOC 2 compliance)
quotes.text: Also, if you want to sell it to the enterprise, proving security is essential.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Connects compliance to enterprise go-to-market success, making security proof a prerequisite rather than a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta (SOC 2 compliance)
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the high-leverage, binary impact of SOC 2 on deal flow and growth timelines.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta (SOC 2 compliance)
quotes.text: Over 3,000 fast growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides concrete adoption and efficiency data points that quantify how much compliance work can be automated.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta (SOC 2 compliance)
quotes.text: Vanta can get you ready for security audits in weeks instead of months, less than a third of the time that it usually takes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives a specific time-to-audit improvement benchmark practitioners can use to evaluate compliance tooling ROI.

quotes.topic_title: The Product Leader Canyon and manager death spiral
quotes.text: you have to shift from doer to editor is the way I think about it.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for the IC-to-manager transition: your leverage comes from improving others’ work, not doing it yourself.

quotes.topic_title: The Product Leader Canyon and manager death spiral
quotes.text: You have to shift from, "My job is to do the work," to, "My job is to make the work better. My job is to plus the work, to review the work, to help other people solve problem."
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Actionable reframing of a manager’s role toward coaching, review, and amplification rather than direct execution.

quotes.topic_title: The Product Leader Canyon and manager death spiral
quotes.text: I actually think of it as start thinking in terms of being lazy, "What's the least amount of work I could do to make this thing as good as possible?" versus, "How do I do as much work as possible to make sure it's great?"
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Counterintuitive ROI lens for management: optimize for minimal high-leverage input instead of maximal personal effort.

quotes.topic_title: The Product Leader Canyon and manager death spiral
quotes.text: When you're a leader, it's now your job to propose, "What are the resources we need to have the most impact on this problem?"
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Defines a key leadership shift from working within constraints to actively shaping and securing the right resourcing.

quotes.topic_title: The Product Leader Canyon and manager death spiral
quotes.text: It's your job to marshal resources both inside your org and across your organization.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Concrete guidance on how leaders scale impact: by coordinating and pulling in resources beyond their immediate team.

quotes.topic_title: Four types of product work for leaders
quotes.text: for every great product leader, you go from being an expert in some type of product work, and I'll describe what those are, to now owning a portfolio of work across a bunch of different dimensions.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A clear leadership progression model: moving from depth in one area to managing a balanced portfolio across multiple product work types.

quotes.topic_title: Four types of product work for leaders
quotes.text: There are two forms of product market fit expansion. There's either taking the same product and finding a new audience. Things like internationalization or vertical like, "I'm going to sell the same product to a different vertical because we're a verticalized product." The other is selling a different product to the same audience. This is what bundling strategies basically look like.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A practical taxonomy for PMF expansion that helps leaders choose between new segments vs. new products (bundling) as distinct strategic paths.

quotes.topic_title: Four types of product work for leaders
quotes.text: there's the fourth that is always forgotten by a lot of PMs which is scaling work.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that scaling work is a core product pillar, not just an engineering concern, and is commonly under-prioritized.

quotes.topic_title: Four types of product work for leaders
quotes.text: Most people think of this as technical scaling, but I actually put things like trust, and safety, and other kinds of what we call user scaling problems in this as well.
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: Expands the definition of scaling beyond infrastructure to include trust/safety and user-scale issues—useful for planning resourcing and roadmaps.

quotes.topic_title: Four types of product work for leaders
quotes.text: We've all seen this. Right? It's like growth leader takes over, and everything is a growth problem. Everything is an experiment. Everything should be measured. That's not necessarily true for some of these other kinds of work, and so how do you start to lead, and grow, and build a portfolio across those?
quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.context: A caution against over-applying one’s specialty (e.g., growth) to all problems, pushing leaders to adapt their approach across different work types.
